Thousands of customers have successfully migrated to the AWS cloud and run successful workloads that are secure, available, and reliable. Customers will learn best from the case studies of companies who are similar to them in size, industry, workload, etc. \\n\\n\*\*ArisGlobal performs successful and compliant migration in a highly regulated industry.\*\*\\nArisGlobal delivers software solutions to major life sciences organizations, helping them streamline the drug development process. Aris Global was interested in cloud migration but they were hesitant to migrate because of the industry regulations they must meet. After carefully considering their cloud options, ArisGlobal decided on AWS, trusting that AWS would keep their customer data secure. AWS is ISO/IEC 27001, SOC 2, HIPAA, and the General Data Protection Regulation compliant. Using Database Migration Service \(DMS\), ArisGlobal migrated over 100TB of database workloads to Amazon RDS for Oracle. They completed the initial migration using a lift and shift strategy, and have since been utilizing other AWS services to optimize the workload. They use Elasticache for Redis to cache the data, and deliver it with lower latency. They also optimized using Amazon Elasticsearch service and Elastic Kubernetes Service \(EKS\). With the successful completion of their migration, ArisGlobal successfully launched LifeSphere, a Software as a Solution \(SaaS\) cloud platform for pharmaceutical companies. ArisGlobal is enjoying benefits such as 50% less database hits, eliminated licensing fees, and reduced troubleshooting time from 35-45 minutes to seconds, and automated deployments in minutes.^^1^^\\n\\n\*\*The world’s largest retailer, Amazon, successfully leaves behind legacy databases for cloud-native solutions.\*\*\\nOnline retail powerhouse Amazon.com was created in a time before AWS, when monolithic, on premises databases solutions were the most available and logical for the amount of data Amazon was managing. Amazon had to deal with the complexities of disengaging with legacy databases. Amazon had a fleet of more than 5,000 databases, 50 petabytes of data. The company was also concerned with how the move would impact their employees and if employees would leave as a result of the transition. However, the cost associated with licensing on Oracle led Amazon to take on the large task. Amazon utilized schema conversion tool \(SCT\) and database migration service to make their heterogenous migration possible. For some workloads, they opted to migrate to Amazon Aurora. They also opted to migrate a large number of their critical workloads to DynamoDB, an AWS fully managed NoSQL database. As a result of their migration, Amazon cut database operating costs by 50% and lowered the latency of most critical services by 40%. Additionally, Amazon engineers who were managing the difficulties with Oracle on premises now have the time to innovate on behalf of customers rather than deal with databases.^^2^^\\n\\n\*\*Expedia significantly lowers latency of payment processing for travelers and vendors globally.\*\*\\nExpedia Group \(Expedia\) leads the way as a constantly growing online travel platform. Taking and delivering payments on global scale is a large part of Expedia’s business model. Expedia owns multiple booking sites, handling travelers from over 70 countries, and more than 80 different currencies. Expedia was experiencing delays in their account payable reconciliation \(APRecon\), leading to a domino of effect that impacted end users. Their current APRecon was running on SQL Server, leading to vendor lock in and high costs. After examining their options in the cloud and on premises, Expedia ultimately decided to migrate to Amazon Aurora PostgreSQL. The switch to Aurora, as well as using Amazon Simple Queue Service \(SQS\), Simple Storage Service \(S3\) and the Matching and Reconciliation System \(MARS\) to decouple their infrastructure and implement scalable microservices. As a result of making these changes on AWS, Expedia was able to reduce their manual touch rate for processing partner payments from 17% to 0.06%. They are also able to deliver near real time data to their users and vendors in less than 1 second, rather than the previous system when there was a processing time of more than 1 day.^^3^^ \\n\\n\*\*Cathay Pacific Airlines increases performance and lowers downtime with successful migration to AWS.\*\*\\nCathay Pacific Airlines \(Cathay Pacific\) is a Hong Kong based airline, operating both passenger and cargo flights in over 200 locations globally. Cathay Pacific needs to ensure their Passenger Revenue Optimization System \(PROS\) is running efficiently and securely to ensure they are optimizing revenue and customers can rely on the airline to handle booking appropriately. Cathay had already migrated more than 65 of their applications to AWS, cutting their costs by 50% and speeding up the software development cycle by 67%. Prior to migrating the PROS, Cathay had increased their availability from 99.5% to 99.9% from 2019 to 2020. Despite these successes, Cathay was hesitant to migrate to the PROS because of the size and computing power required from the system. Due to the trust Cathay had in AWS from prior success, they chose to migrate the system to Amazon RDS for Oracle. The switch to RDS lead to a 20% increase in performance for the system and shortened the downtime during backups windows from 10 hours to 6-7 hours. AWS also allowed them to automate security processes, freeing staff to focus on innovation. This extra time for innovation helped them to further improve the customer booking experience with new software features.^^4^^\\n\\n\*\*Experian successfully expands business model and services offered due to AWS database migration.\*\*\\nAfter being known mostly as a credit bureau, Experian made business decisions to expand their footprint. They also wanted to be known as a company that assists individually and businesses in utilizing the power of data to drive decisions, helps to prevent fraud, and assists people in taking control of their overall financial life. As Experian made the decision to grow and expand, they knew their on-premises architecture would not support the company any longer. They made the decision to focus on AWS microservices to decouple their architecture and increase scalability and security. Their first major move was from Microsoft SQL Server to DynamoDB, an AWS fully manage NoSQL solution. As a part of their growth, Experian acquired CSIdentity \(CSID\) and then chose to migrate to Amazon Aurora MySQL to replace their legacy relational database. Immediately after acquiring CSID, Experian first migrated the database system to an EC2 instance running the MySQL database. Later, they decided to modernize the system by migrating to Aurora. The move from EC2 to Aurora saw a 10% improvement in response times, replication lag times were cut in half, backup runtime decreased by 95%, and cost decreased by 35%. CSID now experiences 100% uptime. Experian was able to free themselves from only offering credit reports to using the capabilities of DynamoDB and Aurora to provide users with a more complete image of the financial identity.^^5^^ \\n\\n\*\*Pokémon Company is able to securely accommodate over 300 million users with AWS fully managed database services.\*\*\\nJapan based Pokémon has been a leading entertainment company since 1996, creating stable products such as trading cards and the Pokémon GO game. Pokémon supports user accounts to allow users to track their achievements in the mobile game and with trading cards. The user profile system consists of two large sets of data for the two sectors of the company. The two sectors require different processes and maintenance, making the task more complex. The popular Pokémon GO mobile game lead the number of users to increase to more than 300 million in just two years. Pokémon was outsourcing to a NoSQL document database with fast read times, but they ran into issues managing more than 300 complex nodes and indices to achieve the speed they wanted. When certain nodes went down, users would lose access to the system and the operating team had to leave all other work to get the node back up and running. Pokémon was already using EC2, Elastic Load Balancer and S3 with success, and decided to migrate to AWS fully managed database services, using Amazon Aurora PostgreSQL. After the migration, the company was able to lessen the number of nodes from 300 to 30, monthly costs have dropped by tens of thousands of dollars, and after having 168 hours of downtime/performance degradation in the past 6 months, they have had zero hours since migrating. They have also modernized using DynamoDB TTL to track log in attempts and deny entry at the threshold, helping to limit the number of bot log in attempts and Elasticache service to reduce the time spent managing Memcached nodes for the company.^^6^^ \\n\\n\*\*Decisiv learns the true value of cloud migration, freeing their employees to focus on innovation.\*\*\\nDecisiv is a startup delivering cloud-based service relationship management \(SRM\) SaaS solutions for the commercial trucking industry to manage their fleets. Decisiv needed a highly available database to support their critical workload as any downtime is a loss of revenue and business to their customers. They also needed a scalable environment to allow their business to grow. The chief technology officer, Satish Joshi, also expressed wanting the development team to be able to create and deploy software at a more rapid pace. The company initially migrated to Amazon RDS for SQL Server, and later modernized by moving the workload to Aurora PostgreSQL. AWS multi availably zone deployment increased their uptime from 98 percent to over 99 percent for their critical workload. Decisiv also doubled their development productivity, benefitting from the agility of AWS to provision new environments in days, compared to weeks or months. When the company modernized from RDS for SQL server to Aurora PostgreSQL, they were able to combine multiple databases into a single Aurora instance. Picture this: Your team wants to move to AWS, but you're stuck in authentication hell. Legacy systems that don't play nice together. Manual key management that feels like juggling dynamite. Security reviews that take forever. Sound familiar?

**You're not alone.** Before CloudAuth, teams at Amazon faced the same nightmare:
- Complex AAA-Symmetric setups that required thick clients and lengthy bootstrap processes
- Network fabric limitations blocking cross-environment calls  
- Manual relationship management consuming precious engineering time
- Security gaps when moving between Prod/Corp and AWS environments

---

## **Meet CloudAuth: Your Authentication Superhero**

CloudAuth is Amazon's **OAuth2-based unified authentication service** that makes secure service-to-service communication as simple as it should be. Think of it as the universal translator for your services - whether they're in Prod/Corp, Public AWS, or anywhere in between.

**Here's the magic:** CloudAuth uses industry-standard OAuth2 protocols but extends them with Amazon's battle-tested AAA relationship data. You get the simplicity of modern standards with the power of Amazon's proven security model.

---

## **The Top 5 Game-Changing Benefits**

### 🌐 **#1: True Cross-Environment Freedom**
**Finally, break down those network barriers!** CloudAuth works seamlessly across ANY Amazon network fabric - Prod to AWS, AWS to AWS, Corp to Prod - you name it. No more "sorry, that won't work across environments."

*Real Impact:* Teams like Translation and Localization accelerated their AWS adoption because they could keep their existing Prod/Corp investments while embracing new AWS technologies.

### ⚡ **#2: Zero Heavy Lifting Required**
**No daemons, no thick clients, no complex bootstrap processes.** CloudAuth is lightweight and cloud-native from day one. Your Lambda functions, ECS tasks, and EC2 instances just work - even in dynamic environments where traditional solutions fall flat.

*Real Impact:* 1 billion data points processed every 5 minutes across 35,000+ services with minimal operational overhead.

### 🔒 **#3: Security That Actually Scales**
**Built on OAuth2 with end-to-end TLS - because security shouldn't be an afterthought.** CloudAuth requires secure connections throughout, eliminating man-in-the-middle vulnerabilities that plague other solutions. Plus, it's fully certified and endorsed by InfoSec.

*Real Impact:* Automatic security audit trails through SEL integration means zero-effort compliance for your team.

### 🚀 **#4: Developer Experience That Delights**
**Integrated with all your favorite Amazon frameworks** - Coral, ARest, BSF, and more. Your developers can focus on building features instead of fighting authentication. Framework upgrades handle the heavy lifting.

*Real Impact:* Development teams report dramatic productivity increases as they shift from managing auth infrastructure to delivering customer value.

### 💰 **#5: Future-Proof Innovation Engine**
**You're not just getting authentication - you're getting a platform.** CloudAuth comes with Transitive Auth for fine-grained access control, supports AI agent workflows, pluggable authorization, and regional flexibility. Plus, the UnifiedAuth team continuously adds new capabilities.

*Real Impact:* Teams using CloudAuth automatically get advanced features like FGAC and compliance reporting without additional integration work.

---

**"CloudAuth has accelerated our ability to adopt AWS for service deployment"** - Bill Kaper, Senior Software Development Manager, Translation and Localization. His team moved from being blocked by authentication complexity to embracing AWS technologies while maintaining their existing Prod/Corp investments.

**Customer Impact:** Services see 50% reduction in database operating costs and 40% lower latency on critical services after adopting CloudAuth-enabled architectures.

---

## **But What About...?**

**"Isn't this just another proprietary solution?"** 
Actually, no! CloudAuth is built on industry-standard OAuth2. Your team can use existing OAuth libraries with minimal modifications. You're investing in standards, not lock-in.

**"We're not ready for a big migration project..."**
Perfect! CloudAuth supports gradual adoption. You can run CloudAuth alongside existing AAA systems, migrating services at your own pace. No big-bang required.

**"What about regions where CloudAuth isn't available?"**
The UnifiedAuth team is rapidly expanding regional coverage, and you can use BubbleBridge for cross-region connectivity. Plus, alternative solutions remain available for edge cases.

---

Thousands of Amazon services have already made the leap. Teams report faster development cycles, improved security posture, and the freedom to innovate across any environment.

**Ready to transform your authentication story?**

✅ **Get Support:** The CloudAuth team provides full Tier-1 support - the same level as AAA

✅ **Connect:** Join office hours at https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Dev.CDO/UnifiedAuth/Support/OfficeHours

**Don't let authentication be the bottleneck that holds back your team's AWS journey. CloudAuth is here to set you free.**

*The question isn't whether you should adopt CloudAuth - it's how quickly you can get started. Your future self will thank you.*
